evidence.pdf_reference: Ga 2 O 3 was used as a photocatalyst for the photoreduction of CO 2 in the presence of H 2 as a reductant; in this process CO gas was selectively produced at room temperature and ambient pressure.The optimum conversion of CO 2 was approximately 3 using b-Ga 2 O 3 calcined at 1073 K for 6 h.The formation of CO depended on the amounts of H 2 and CO 2 introduced into the system.The photoreduction of CO 2 on Ga 2 O 3 involves two chemisorbed species-H 2 and CO 2 .This implies that the photocatalytic reaction

gas.The change in photoactivity corresponded to the change in the adsorption isotherm of H 2 on b-Ga 2 O 3 .Accordingly, the amount of CO formed by the photoreduction of CO 2 in the presence of H 2 depends on the amount of introduced H 2 gas.This implies that the adsorption of H 2 on b-Ga 2 O 3 involves the photoreduction of CO 2 .We have reported that basic metal oxides such as ZrO 2 12131417,18 and MgO 15,16 exhibit high photocatalytic activity in the photoreduction of CO 2 .We have suggested the

CO 2 was almost saturated in 100 lmol of CO 2 gas introduced in our system.In fact, the amount of CO formed over irradiated b-Ga 2 O 3 was constant when more than 100 lmol of CO 2 gas was introduced.Therefore, the photoreduction of CO 2 in the presence of H 2 as the reductant on irradiated b-Ga 2 O 3 involves two adsorbed species-H 2 and CO 2 .This implies that the photocatalytic reaction would proceed on the basis of the typical Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism.At present, we assume that b-Ga 2 O 3 has not

in the presence of H 2 as the reductant.The adsorption of H 2 on b-Ga 2 O 3 enhanced the photoreduction of CO 2 ; however, this enhancement was not observed in the case of other basic metal oxides such as ZrO 2 and MgO.
the photocatalytic reaction would proceed on the basis of the typical Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism.
